image.altText: A woman's hands hold a human skull.

props.synopsis: SA Police says it had "expertly assessed" several skeletal remains listed for sale by the auction house and the "sale of these anatomically prepared human remains" was not in breach of any state laws.

title.children: Auction house did not break law by selling human bones, police say

image.altText: legs of a young person in jeans in a dark stairwell.

props.synopsis: The SA opposition says the state is in the grip of a "youth crime crisis", and while the state's police chief has denied the situation is "worse than it has ever been", the government has ruled out raising the age of criminal responsibility.Â

title.children: Is SA facing a 'youth crime crisis', and how should it manage young offenders?

image.altText: Henry Thornton of South Australia celebrates, raising his arms and extending his index fingers

props.synopsis: South Australia's triumphant cricketers are setting their sights on a historic double, after winning the one-day competition for the first time in 13 years.

title.children: South Australia end 13-year drought with One Day Cup triumph

image.altText: On stage, four women in pink netball uniforms stand on a makeshift court. One smiles, hands on hips, as another glares at her.

props.synopsis: Why aren't there more musicals about netball? It's the question you didn't know you wanted answered. Step behind the scenes of an energetic, hot-pink netball musical with a Shakespearean twist.

title.children: What position would Lady Macbeth play in netball, asks new musical

image.altText: Beaumont children photo

props.synopsis: A seven-day search for the Beaumont children, who went missing from Glenelg Beach in 1966, has concluded after "almost 10,000 tonnes" of soil was dug up as part of the "biggest clandestine grave dig in the world".

title.children: 'We can walk away satisfied': Search for Beaumont children concludes

image.altText: A red sold sticker across a for sale sign outside a house with a large front yard on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: Home values jumped in the month the Reserve Bank cut interest rates, with Australia looking to have exited one of its shortest and mildest property downturns on record.

title.children: Victoria becomes 'the first home buyer state' as prices rebound nationally

image.altText: A man with grey hair and a grey goatee smiling while leaning back in a lounge chair.

props.synopsis: An experienced South Australian snake catcher has spent a week in hospital after being bitten by a lice-infested snake he was treating with a bath.

title.children: One lousy bath leaves snake catcher in hot water

image.altText: Rhoda Roberts holding on to a boxing bag.

props.synopsis: A new stage show at this year's Adelaide Festival shines a light on the struggles that one of Australia's first Indigenous Olympians faced both in and out of the boxing ring, and on his battle for securing recognition and respect inside his own country. Warning: This story contains the image and name of an Indigenous person who has died.

title.children: He was a trailblazer in the ring, now his battle is being celebrated on stage

image.altText: Close up image of lamb and other meat in a cabinet at a butcher

props.synopsis: While many meat eaters have opted for local butchers over supermarkets in recent years, some butchers say they are finding it tough to find and retain qualified staff and apprentices.Â

title.children: Local butchers bounce back, but staffing is a challenge

image.altText: A composite image of two men, both in suits, looking on.

props.synopsis: It is doubtless that viewers in Russia would have recognised some of the same talking points as the Ukrainian president was berated by Donald Trump and his attack dog of a vice-president, JD Vance.

title.children: It wasn't just Americans watching a classic of the Trump reality TV genre

image.altText: A close-up of an Australian Army patch and an Australian flag patch on an ADF officer's uniform.

props.synopsis: A former defence department deputy secretary says Australia must spend more on its military capability, despite the difficulty in selling the policy in a cost-of-living crisis. Follow live.Â

title.children: Australia urged to lift defence spending despite being a 'hard sell' to voters

image.altText: Vincent Fantauzzo

props.synopsis: How the famous portrait of the Hollywood actor forged an enduring bond between his grieving father and the artist, Vincent Fantauzzo.

title.children: How Heath Ledger's death changed Vincent Fantauzzo's life

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and Peter Dutton stand next to each other.

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese and Peter Dutton send clear signals that we stand as a nation with Ukraine but they are not dealing with the deeper reality that our once reliable American partner is no longer reliable in the same way.

title.children: Our alliance with the US is in crisis under Trump

image.altText: An outdoor shopping strip.

props.synopsis: The ABC spoke to a number of people living in St Albans, in Melbourne's west, on issues that they see as key ahead of the federal election.Â

title.children: In Melbourne's west, cost-of-living pressures could sway key contests

image.altText: The Star, Brisbane 2025-01-09 10:01:00

props.synopsis: Star failed to report its financial results on Friday, leaving shares suspended from trade without a further update. Wall Street rebounded late on Friday, giving impetus to the ASX this morning. Follow live.

image.altText: Side-by-side photos of Bianca Jones and Holly Bowles, two Melbourne teens

props.synopsis: Months after the deaths of Holly Bowles and Bianca Jones, their families say they are furious at the lack of information from Lao authorities and want travellers to boycott the country until a proper investigation is held.

title.children: Parents of methanol poisoning victims describe investigation as 'disgraceful'

image.altText: Close up of phone with someone about to place a bet on a sports game

props.synopsis: About $32 billion a year is now lost by people betting online, mostly by those who can't afford it. A bill that would force online betting outfits to display to each client what they're losing, and what they've lost, each time they log on is hoped to change that.

title.children: We lose $32b a year to online gambling. A new bill might help reduce it

image.altText: A Qantas plane taxies along a runway in overcast conditions while passengers seated inside watch on.

props.synopsis: Pacific Islanders spending large amounts of money trying to secure Australia's new permanent residency visa say the experience has left them dejected and anxious.

title.children: Applicants spend big, lose job offers as new visa scheme rolled out

props.synopsis: Around the clock coverage of news events as they break at home and abroad.

title.children: ABC News Channel live

image.altText: pope francis sits in wheelchair and waves

title.children: Pope no longer needs breathing ventilator, Vatican says

image.altText: Varun Chakravarthy celebrates with Virat Kohli

props.synopsis: Australia was proven right to travel to Dubai early as it has now discovered it will play India there on Tuesday in the Champions Trophy semifinals.

title.children: Australia's early flight gamble pays off as India sets up semifinal clash

image.altText: A close up view of a smoke stack at the Whyalla steelworks, taken at sunset

props.synopsis: Some business and climate groups have voiced their support for keeping one of the federal government's key climate policies in place, with the Coalition yet to commit to its future.

title.children: Australia's key climate policy faces an uncertain future

props.synopsis: A former teacher takes a Victorian Catholic school to the Fair Work Commission, alleging she was fired after raising concerns about bullying within staff.

title.children: Private school teacher allegedly sacked after flagging staff bullying

image.altText: An image of a concrete and wood apartment square block.

title.children: 'Cookie cutter' pattern book designs missing the mark, says architect

image.altText: A lady with a headscarf, smiling and looking at the camera.

props.synopsis:
Young people consume vast amounts of information on personal finance on social media. But that thirst for financial knowledge is not translating into action when it comes to them managing their superannuation.

title.children: Millennials missing out on thousands of dollars by ignoring their super

image.altText: Residential houses on a hill at sunset.

props.synopsis: Investing expert Margaret Lomas climbed the property ladder over decades, which delivered her housing and financial security. We meet desperate first home buyers and explain why emulating this success is now impossible.

title.children: ABC News Daily: The great (investor) dream

image.altText: A pair of hands typing on a laptop. A red Griffith sign in the background.

props.synopsis: A man was incorrectly charged under his brother's name over a decade old hack on Griffith University despite Australian authorities being told the accused man was in New Zealand.

title.children: Man accused of decade-old uni hack allegedly found in NZ with three passports

image.altText: A chinese aircraft

props.synopsis: While flying remains the safest mode of transport, global aviation fatalities more than tripled between 2023 and 2024.

title.children: Worries after report finds global aviation risk doubled

image.altText: boxing glove

props.synopsis: Some parents say they saw an almost immediate improvement in their children's self-confidence after starting martial arts. But it's not about using violence to address violence.

title.children: Frustrated with bullying, these parents enrolled their kids in self-defence

image.altText: A person holding a sign reading, North Stoneville stranded

props.synopsis: Opposition to a controversial housing development in Perth's rural fringe has reached boiling point amid dual election campaigns, as politicians from all persuasions jump on the cause.

title.children: All sides of politics unite against controversial Perth hills development

image.altText: A person sifting flour into a pancake mixture

props.synopsis: This week kicks off the period leading up to the Christian Easter celebrations. But while Easter is typically associated with hot cross buns and chocolate eggs, there's another sweet treat to indulge in: pancakes.Â

title.children: Why do people make pancakes on Shrove Tuesday?

image.altText: photo from a height of a power station with the sea in the background

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory government is planning to extend the life of an almost four-decade-old gas-fired power station, as it seemingly retreats from its target of 50 per cent renewable energy by 2030.

title.children: NT retreats from renewables target, extends life of gas power plant
